title: Treasury Yields Edge Higher After Fed Signal on Tapering Bond Buying
sub_head: Central bank says U.S. economy has made progress toward its employment and inflation goals
body:
U.S. government bond yields edged higher Wednesday after the Federal Reserve signaled it was getting closer to when it could start tapering bond purchases.
The yield on the benchmark 10-year Treasury note, which helps set borrowing costs on everything from mortgages to corporate debt, settled at 1.259%, according to Tradeweb, compared with 1.254% just before the Fed’s policy statement and 1.235% at Tuesday’s close.
Short-term yields, which are especially sensitive to changes in monetary policy, also edged higher, with the yield on the 5-year Treasury note increasing to 0.739% from 0.694% on Tuesday.
Yields, though, retreated in after-hours trading, suggesting investors were continuing to assess the implications of the meeting while retaining a solid appetite for Treasurys.
Investors initially reacted to the Fed’s policy statement by selling Treasurys, focusing on a single sentence that suggested officials are thinking more seriously about reducing its purchases of Treasurys and mortgage-backed securities.
